{{Infobox baseball biography | name = Carol Habben | image = Carol Habben.jpg | image_size = 175px | team = [[All-American Girls Professional Baseball League]] | position = [[Center fielder]] / [[Utility player|Utility]] | birth_date= {{birth date|1933|5|15|mf=y}} | birth_place= [[Midland Park, New Jersey]] | death_date= {{death date and age|1997|1|11|1933|5|15}} | death_place= [[Ridgewood, New Jersey]] | bats = Right | throws = Right | debutyear = | debutteam = | finalyear = | finalteam = | stat1label = [[Batting average]] | stat1value = .231 | stat2label = [[Home run]]s | stat2value =    15 | stat3label = [[Runs batted in]] | stat3value =    65 | teams =<nowiki></nowiki> *[[Rockford Peaches]] (1951-1953) *[[Kalamazoo Lassies]] (1954) |highlights=<nowiki></nowiki> *AAGPBL Champion Team (1954) }}
'''Carol Habben''' (May 15, 1933 - January 11, 1997) was a [[center fielder]] and backup [[catcher]] who played from {{by|1951}} through {{by|1954}} in the [[All-American Girls Professional Baseball League]]. Listed at 5' 5", 135 lb., she batted and threw [[right-handed]].<ref name=AAGPBL-Habben>{{cite web |url=http://www.aagpbl.org/players/index.cfm?do=player.details&playerid=314 |title= AAGPBL website â Carol Habben entry}}</ref>
The All-American Girls Professional Baseball League flourished in the 1940s when [[Major League Baseball]] went on hold as men went to [[World War II]]. The league was created in 1943 by the [[Chicago Cubs]]' owner [[Philip K. Wrigley]], and disbanded at the end of the 1954 season. In its twelve years of history, the AAGPBL gave over 600 women athletes the opportunity to play professional baseball and to play it at a level never before attained.<ref>[http://www.aagpbl.org/league/history.cfm AAGPBL History]</ref>
It was not really a well known fact until filmmaker [[Penny Marshall]] premiered her [[1992 in film|1992 film]] ''[[A League of Their Own]]'', which was a [[fiction]]alized account of activities in the AAGPBL. Starring [[Geena Davis]], [[Tom Hanks]], [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], [[Lori Petty]] and [[Rosie O'Donnell]], this film brought many of the real AAGPBL former players began to earn a rebirth of celebrity.<ref>[http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0104694/ IMDb.com â ''A League of Their Own'' (1992 film)]</ref>
==Early life== Born in [[Midland Park, New Jersey]], Carol Habben began playing ball on sandlots in [[Rahway, New Jersey|Rahway]] at age 12 and joined the Flashettes of [[Garfield, New Jersey|Garfield]] two years later. In the process, Habben played baseball at [[Pompton Lakes High School]]. At age 17, she attended to an AAGPBL tryout and signed a contract for $250 a month to play in the league. While still in high school, she had to take her exams early in order to make it for the start of the 1951 season.<ref>''Encyclopedia of Women and Baseball'' - Leslie A. Heaphy, Mel Anthony May. Publisher: McFarland & Co., 2006. Format: Paperback, 438 pp. Language: English. ISBN 0-7864-2100-2</ref><ref name=NYT-Obit>{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/14/sports/carol-habben-63-ex-baseball-player.html |title= New York Times - Carol Habben obituary | work=The New York Times | date=January 14, 1997}}</ref>
==AAGPBL career== Habben entered the league with the [[Rockford Peaches]]. She was a late bloomer, but turned out to be a formidable [[slugging percentage|slugger]] during the AAGPBL's last-ever season.
In 1951, Habben went 1-for-26 for a pale [[batting average]] of 0.38 as a [[rookie]], and saw limited action the next season. In 1953, she hit .194 with a .238 [[on-base percentage]] in an [[utility player|utility role]], playing at [[outfield]], catching, and also [[pitcher|pitching]] in case of an emergency. Then she was dealt by Rockford to the [[Kalamazoo Lassies]] before the 1954 season.<ref>''The Women of the All-American Girls Professional Baseball League: A biographical dictionary'' - W. C. Madden. Publisher: McFarland & Co., 1997. Format: Paperback, 295 pp. Language: English. ISBN 0-7864-0304-7</ref>
Habben showed exactly how much power she had in her bat when the AAGPBL's [[Baseball (ball)|ball]] switched to 9 Â¼ inchesâthe same size of a baseball used in the Major Leagues.<ref>[http://www.aagpbl.org/league/rules.cfm AAGPBL Rules of Play]</ref>
As everyday center fielder in 1954, Habben hit a .276 average with a .363 OBP in 98 games, while slugging for a .445 average to become the second half of the called ''Home Run Twins'', as she hit 15 home runs and [[Chris Ballingall]] belted 17 to power the Lassies to the Championship Title.<ref name="EWB">Encyclopedia of Women and Baseball</ref><ref>[http://www.aagpbl.org/articles/biographies.cfm?ID=17 AAGPBL website â June Peppas biography by Jim Sargent]</ref>
==Life after baseball== After the AAGPBL folded, Habben returned to New Jersey, competing in [[Amateur Softball Association|ASA]] [[fast-pitch softball]] in [[Linden, New Jersey|Linden]] until 1973, and also [[Umpire (baseball)|umpiring]] in men's and women's leagues.<ref name=NYT-Obit/>
Habben lived in [[Ringwood, New Jersey|Ringwood]] and worked 37 years for [[Merck & Co.]] as a credit manager until her retirement in 1994. She is part of the AAGPBL permanent display at the [[Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum]] at [[Cooperstown, New York]], opened in {{by|1988}}, which is dedicated to the entire league rather than any individual player.<ref name=NYT-Obit/>
Carol Habben spent the last days of her life in [[Ridgewood, New Jersey]], where she died of a long illness at the age of 63.<ref name=AAGPBL-Habben/>
